message_1: Consider a sample of a radioactive isotope containing 200 grams which has a half-life of 10 years. How much of the isotope will remain after 30 years have passed?
message_2:
To determine the remaining amount of the radioactive isotope after 30 years, we can use the formula:

Remaining amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount is 200 grams, the half-life is 10 years, and the time elapsed is 30 years. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Remaining amount = 200 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)

Remaining amount = 200 * (1/2)^3

Remaining amount = 200 * (1/8)

Remaining amount = 25 grams

So, after 30 years, 25 grams of the radioactive isotope will remain.
